text: Nervous system regulation is a really popular approach these days and for very good reason it can be really useful but there are some big misunderstandings around it and it does have limitations that I want to explore in this video because it's often described as if it's the goal of healing work that you know you just excuse me you just regulate your nervous system and then you can sail off into the sunset and that's what we need to be doing here that's kind of the work is to regulate the nervous system and that's a bit of a misunderstanding so to understand this let's get into what dysregulation is nervous system dysregulation is when your nervous system is stuck in a survival state it could be hyper aroused so stuck in fight or flight or hypo aroused when it's stuck in a sort of a dorsal vagal like shut down uh feeling numb disconnected and it's unable to move out of that so it's chronically stuck in in one of those two states or going between the two and what's driving that is almost like a backlog of emotional pain of traumatic trapped energy that you've accumulated through your life you know you go through life you have these traumatic experiences nervous system responses come up but if they're too overwhelming you have to push them back down and it gets sort of trapped in the body and you end up you can almost imagine like like a kind of a bucket of emotional pain and survival energy that's kind of stored within you as you go through life it gets more and more and more and more and your nervous system has a certain capacity as well everyone's nervous system is different and so that's kind of like the size of the bucket and as as the you know amount of trauma gets higher or the bucket gets smaller which can also happen you become very sensitive to triggers because these energies they want to resolve themselves they want to come up that that that you know the emotions want to come and be felt that nervous system response is always looking out for an opportunity to come up and complete itself and it makes you very susceptible to being triggered right so you end up in this situation where just being alive just going to work you know all these different energies and are being triggered so you just get up and you straight away you feel anxious and afraid or depressed it's because there's all this emotional pain which isn't safe to allow this is the key to all of it this stuff it feels way too overwhelming it's being shut down simultaneously and so you end up feeling very stuck this is why you know when you're anxious for example it feels like there's all this energy that wants to move and yet you're totally frozen at the same time it's like the accelerator and the brake is on at the same time which is like almost what dysregulation is it feels like you're being torn in two directions at once what nervous system regulation does is helps put that balance that out put that all in the box if you imagine that bucket is spilling everywhere right when you're triggered you got the bucket there with all this pain suddenly you get triggered by a small thing the bucket's shaking everywhere and then all your pain is kind of going everywhere that's the state of dysregulation where it's exceeding your bucket's ability to hold it and then nervous system regulation you're putting it back in the bucket which is really helpful it's like if you're really triggered at work you get really angry at work you can do some nervous system regulation exercises and that anger will come off the boil you'll come back from that anger to a more grounded state more quickly if your partner says something and you shut down you freeze you can notice that you can regulate yourself and you can come out of that freeze more quickly and this is really really helpful and it's a powerful prerequisite for a lot of the deeper trauma work but here's the issue it doesn't actually address the contents of the bucket so it doesn't address the root which is the emotional pain and that trapped survival energy that you're holding in your body and have been holding for decades and so as a result of that if you only take nervous system regulation as your goal you have to do it forever you're going to be doing your nervous system regulation exercises every day every time you go to work every time your partner triggers you you have to do your stuff Your exercises and you can end up with some, you know, people have these crazy self-care routines That I understand they need them, but it's not something you want to be doing for the rest of your life necessarily You know is spending two hours every morning Going through your meditation and your yoga and grounding exercises and hape or whatever it is Those are all great. But there's there's just more to it than this, right? The the solution where you want to go is actually reducing the Contents of the bucket or substantially increasing the capacity of your nervous system Both of which are kind of you know, can they kind of go hand in hand? This is why actually meeting and processing the emotional trauma itself So this is different because regulating is it's kind of like you're you're putting it back in the box Processing is you're helping it move through up and through so regulation is like down and back in the box Processing is up and through So it's like when that anger comes up at work and you don't want to do this at work But you could do it afterwards when you get home you're letting that anger come up and fully feeling the anger all the way through and That when you when you've done that when you fully meet something without resistance embodying it allowing it listening to it Letting your fists cleanse like I'm so angry It Actually moves through and completes itself and then integrates and dissolves and that part of your bucket isn't there anymore Then the key thing is you don't need to regulate anymore because there's nothing to regulate The next time your boss says that thing you won't get a reaction Inside you because there's nothing to be triggered. And so there's no need to regulate right and Regulation is helpful here regulation can give you the space to start to do this work, which is why it's so useful You know, if you're completely on edge all the time, it's too overwhelming to process some of this stuff you need to be able to build a more flexible nervous system that can move in and out of Survival states really flexibly. That's what nervous system regulation helps you to learn It's like okay I can go into anger and I can come back to being grounded I can go into a bit of shutdown and come back And it's that that's a really powerful prerequisite for doing in the emotional processing work. And then with that, eventually, the goal is that you don't need to regulate yourself at all. I don't really do any nervous system regulation anymore. I don't have to, because I processed a lot of my emotions. And so I get triggered a tiny fraction of the percentage of what used to be the case, right? And this is a much easier way of going through life than then having to just do lots of nervous system regulation exercises every day. So I wanted to just make that really crystal clear that that's the difference between the two and why you may need to do just a ton of regulation work upfront to prepare yourself to be doing some of the processing. That's great. It's really helpful stuff and there's tons of good information out there. But I just want you to know that's definitely not the whole picture. And actually where you wanna be going, you don't wanna make that your goal or intention for your healing journey. You wanna make the processing the intention and the goal. And then over time, you have to regulate yourself less and less and less because your nervous system, your bucket's empty and then it's fine. Then if something happens to you in life, it fills up a little bit and you've got plenty of capacity to deal with it. So I hope that clarified a few things. If you wanna learn more, I've got various resources on my website, different nervous system regulation tools, in fact. And also I work with people one-on-one to help them process their emotions. See you next time.
